newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends firmer but most gains pared.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends firmer but most gains pared.

text.p: COMEX copper settled barely higher after losing most of the gains made early in a hesitant and relatively rangebound session.
Most active December rose to 93.90 cents, its highest since September 5 as LME three-months broke through a key upside technical barrier.
Once the technical picture improved, uncertainty surrounding the resurgent Sumitomo scandal encouraged some profit taking on the highs, Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities said.
"Nevertheless we are facing the potential for short-term supply tightness. Fabricators say they cannot get their hands quickly on material in the U.S. and in Europe," Raptopoulos said.
December COMEX ended 0.50 cent firmer at 92.95 cents per pound, traded 93.90 to 92.50 cents. Spot October went out 1.20 cents firmer at 96.90 cents.
Volume was estimated at 12,000 lots, compared to an official 9,028 lots on Tuesday. Switches on Wednesday totalled 1,122.
Union members at Kennecott Utah Copper Corp were voting Wednesday and Thursday on a new six-year labor deal.
Traders said they expected stocks at the LME warehouse in Long Beach to continue falling with one broker forecasting a dip of 15,000 to 20,000 tonnes over the coming few weeks.
The metal is going to three locations - the COMEX warehouse in Tucson, to consumers in the U.S. Midwest, and to the Far East, brokers said.
Long Beach holds 40,125 tonnes of copper, the largest concentration of LME copper stocks after Hamburg's 58,350 tones.
LME stocks total 159,350 tonnes, while COMEX stocks have been rising and reached 22,314 short tons Tuesday.
